page.lettertext:
fol.271r
Belgia 1590. Septem
b:
Belgia. 1590 10 Septem
b
To M
r
Bodly
Elizabeth R
Trusty and welbeloved we greet you well. Although we did verie latelie c
o
maund o
r
Th
re
r of England
in our name to require you w
th
all speede to treate w
th
the
Stat
both in
generall
and w
th
the
Councell
there also, to procure that some
enterprises might be taken in hand w
th
theire forces and ours also, to make some
incursions into the Enemies Countries, and speciallie into
Flaunders
now in the
absence of the
Duke of Parma
w
th
the greatest part of his forces, being nowe
[.] [in]
Fraunce
Yet such is both o
r
earnest desire, and our Judgement to
hasten thesame grounded uppon sondrie great occasions to have it speedelie
taken in hand, and prosented w
th
all earnestnes, as we shall greatlie mislike
and condemne both the Stat
and Councell there, Yf they shoulde not w
th
all theire good willes and powers, and that w
th
out delaie, or sparing of anie
chardge, give order to have these enterprises taken in hand, whereby either
these two effect
, or one is to followe, that is by this both to dampnefie the
Enemy greatlie w
th
out perill, or at the least to dyvert the Enemies
forces now in Fraunce, wherebie the
french king
might be the more free
from danger of his estate, a matter so manifestlie necessarie, as ev
r
y man
of smale understanding can judge how needfull the same is. Wherefore you
shall
the
use all the meanes you can there w
th
the Stat
, and w
th
all
Councellors there both publicklie and privatelie, to take this matter lyvelie in
hande, for w
ch
purpose we have written o
r
earnest l
re
s to thesaide Stat
Generall, w
ch
you shall receave, and in deliv
r
ie thereof use all good
suations
to them not to make anie dilatorie consultation hereof, but forthw
th
to conclude
uppon the executing of such enterprises, as the
Count Moryce
, to whome also
we have written for this purpose, having chardge of theire forces, and
S
r
Francis Vere
having chardge of ours shall w
th
the advise and assistance of
o
r
Forces both in
Berghen
and
Ostende
conclude to be meet. And for
that we fynde also speedelie to put in order certein new forces to be
transported from this our Realme to Ostende, or some other porte on that
Coast, w
ch
maie also Joyne w
th
the forces of those
Low Countries
; We
woulde
fol.271v
Belgia: 1590: Sep
t:
woulde have you to conferre w
th
the partie that of late made an offer
for
Dunkirk
, that it maie be well considered of, as at this tyme when
these forces shalbe in those partes, the said enterprise maie be taken in
hand, whereof we require you speedelie to advertise us his further
purpose, and also to sende us aunsweare to certein Questions sent to
you by our Tresoror of Englande. You shall doe well to give
advice to the Count Moryce and S
r
Francis Vere that according to the
proportion of theire nombers there be sent w
th
them
[.]
by
into Flaunders
a reason
[able]
quantitie of victuell of bread and wyne for one
[moneth]
spare, w
th
in w
ch
tyme it is likelie this service shalbe performed
Gyven under o
r
Signett at o
r
Castle of Windsor the x
th
of
September
1590.
